Introduction

As one of the biggest employers in the Essex region the Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust, recognises the importance of its role within the local community as a provider of work experience and educational placements.

Due to the wide range of employment opportunities available within the Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust, the Trust can offer a variety of potential work experience and shadowing placements to support with educational needs, career aspirations and development of a local pipeline of employees.
The Trust recognises the need to raise awareness of the range of careers available across the group and within the NHS in general.
Scope
MSEFT has produced this policy with the express aims of :
Complying with all statutory requirements and current NHS guidelines;
Promoting the MSEFT and the NHS as an employer off choice;
Providing a safe and valuable experience for work experience candidates;
Ensuring the privacy and dignity of patients and confidentiality of patient information;
Providing a fair and equitable process for all applicants regardless of their sex, race, gender, any disabilities, religion or sexual orientation;
Promoting strong links with local community.
All placements should be of genuine educational value to the student and should not be treated as unpaid labour to perform routine and/or repetitive tasks that have little or no educational benefit.
Definitions

table_items.text: Is defined as a placement on an employer's premises during which the student observes multiple employees in their roles. The student can socially interact with patients and partake in small tasks appropriate for them in order to learn and gain experience. Students receive no financial remuneration for this activity. The term ‘work experience' has no legal status.

Is defined as a placement on an employer's premises in which a student shadows an employee or range of employees going about their normal activities, allowing close observations of jobs which, because of their complexity or for safety or security reasons cannot
be done by the student. Students receive no financial remuneration for this activity. The term ‘work shadowing' has no legal status.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Placement Supervisors
All students on placement will be allocated an appropriate placement supervisor normally by the Head of department authorising the placement. This can be any appropriate member of staff.

The supervisor is responsible for organising the placement programme, undertaking the initial induction and monitoring the student throughout the placement. This will include ensuring any relevant paperwork and a risk assessment is completed. The supervisor may also complete any required evaluation at the end of the placement
Students

The term “student” when used in this policy refers to anyone undertaking a work experience placement or work shadowing placement with MSEFT. The criteria for defining the age and where it is suitable for them to be placed are covered in points 3 and
Children and young people for the purposes of this policy are defined as being those up to the age of 18 years old.
Induction of Students

Induction should be appropriate to the type and duration of the work experience placement. Induction should be carried out by the placement supervisor and should include  Health  and  Safety,  Confidentiality,  (students  must  be  told  to  inform  a member of staff if they think they recognise any patients who are in the area of the placement)  Data  Protection  (GDPR),  Fire  Evacuation,  Control  of  Infection  and anything identified by a risk assessment.

Induction should be local and appropriate but need not be onerous i.e. induction should be “suitable and sufficient” for the purposes of the placement. This should be documented and signed by both the student and supervisor.

If a large cohort (more than 15) of work experience students commenced in one go, a central induction organised by the Work based Learning and Apprenticeship team, will be run on a set date prior to the students coming out into supervised placements.
Uniform/Dress Code
The work experience Student's standard of dress and appearance should be suitable for the type of placement they are undertaking in the Trust.

Students should not wear school uniforms or expect to be given hospital scrubs or uniforms to wear. Students should be advised by the placement supervisor about what is appropriate for their area of work which would include footwear, in line with the Trusts Uniform Policy or departmental dress code.
Students will also be advised on the dress code in the placement confirmation email sent out prior to their placement.
Teacher/Tutor Visits
If and when the need arises for a student to be visited by a teacher/tutor during their placement, prior notification should be given to the student's placement supervisor.
Insurance
The Trust's normal public liability insurance covers students provided the following are met:-
Work Experience/Work Shadowing – a health declaration, confidentiality form and risk assessment have been completed.
The types of work experience placements available within MSEFT Local schools and Colleges

The greatest demand for placements will be from local schools or colleges whose students normally have to undertake a set number of hours/days of work experience as part of their school/college curriculum when they are aged between 15-18 years.
Careers in Medicine (3 day shadowing)

Students who wish to pursue a career in Medicine to become a doctor can apply to do ‘Work Shadowing' of doctors within the Trust. This is administered by the Medical Education Teams based on each of the three sites of the Trust.
For a placement, application should be made to the relevant site Medical Education Manager.
Applications for students who wish to gain a surgical work experience placement should also apply via the relevant Medical Education Manger who will liaise with the Surgical Services care group.

Post COVID-19 a blended approach to work experience will be used with some virtual reality training to minimise patient exposure and risk. This is to enhance the learning experience and maintain safety.
Basildon/Broomfield/Southend

Students who wish to pursue a career in nursing or any other healthcare profession can apply for Work Experience within MSEFT by applying through the work experience and Work based Learning and Apprenticeship team, professional and commissioned education, or people and Organisational Development.
T-Level Work Placements

The Work Experience Placements run alongside a College's T-Level qualification. The student requires 2 days a week for a period of 29 weeks. This is administered by the Work Experience and Work based Learning and Apprenticeship team, Professional and Commissioned Education, People and Organisational development Administration at Basildon Hospital.
Work experience placement procedure
General Work Experience – Non-Medical all sites

Normally the student would be  years old or older and demonstrate a keen interest in pursuing a career in the NHS. The student should be applying to the POD (People & Organisational Development) Team in the Education Centre at Basildon
& Thurrock University Hospital.
The placement will then be organised by the team member who handles work experience and will consist of a period from 1 day or more depending on the requirement of the individual/college placement.
Generally, the majority of placements are  working days in duration of observational work experience shadowing staff member such as Nurses, Healthcare Assistants, Finance Staff and Porters.
The POD team member is responsible for ensuring all paperwork and name badges are organised and administered correctly. Please see Appendix 1 “Work Experience Application Forms”
Older Age Groups and Vocational Links (all sites)

The Trust already has links with local Colleges. Work Experience forms a critical part of vocational programmes for students who are 16+ years. This is facilitated by the Work based Learning and Apprenticeship team with agreement of relevant Heads of Departments. Placements can vary in duration.
There is also a placement that is required to Health and Social Care Students who need 1 day a week over a period of weeks 10-16 weeks.
The Medical Careers Scheme

Normally the student would be  years old or over and be able to demonstrate the desire to pursue a career in Medicine. The student should apply in writing to the Medical Training Manager based in the relevant site Education Centre or Medical Academic Unit.
The placement will be arranged by the Medical Education Team and will normally last up to 10 days work shadowing with relevant doctors.
The Medical Education Training Team are responsible for ensuring all aspects of the placement are organised and administered correctly. See Appendix 2 “The Medical Career Scheme Procedure Notes”
Three (3) Day Shadowing Programme

The student would be  years old or more and be able to demonstrate the desire to pursue a career as a doctor as well as being on target to achieve the required grades. The student should complete the application form found on the intranet Hub intranet page
The completed application form should be emailed to the medical education team on the relevant site.
This is the same for work experience. The placement will be arranged by the Medical Education team to last a maximum ofdays.
The Medical Education Team are responsible for ensuring all aspects of the placement is organised and administered correctly including contracts and consent form.
Three (3) Day Surgical Placement (all sites)

The student would be  years old or more. This programme will be facilitated by the Clinical Facilitator (CF) in the Division, who will ensure that the student understands day by day where they are going and the ground rules of the particular area.
The Clinical Facilitator will also act as a point of contact during the placement.
On any given day there may be the opportunity to go to theatres to see a minor procedure. This will be at the discretion of the Theatre Manager and the operating surgeon.

Students will have to stand aside if a particularly difficult case is discussed during round times. All attendance at the bedside of patients during ward rounds is at the discretion of the Surgical Team. Students will only be observers to all work undertaken.
Application for the surgical placement should be directed to the relevant site Medical Education Manager.
T Levels Placements
These placements will be for two days a week for  weeks. These placements will be administrated by the Work Experience Administration PCE, POD.
Age restrictions
15 Year Old Student
Students can only obtain non-clinical placements within administration departments. 16 – 17 Year Old Students

Students can gain an indirect clinically based healthcare placement such as medical records or out patient's eye clinic. All students must be over 17 to have a placement on a ward or department with direct access to patients. Students under 17 years are excluded from shadowing placements or medical and surgical placements, across all Trust sites.
17 Year Old and Over

Candidates can gain a clinical/medical placement. They can also apply for the 3 Day Shadowing placement (excluding Obstetrics & Gynaecology and Paediatrics) careers in medicine and the 3 Day Surgical Placement.
18 year old and over
Candidates can apply for all types of placements. Areas that can accommodate students include A&E (all sites), The Mortuary, Surgery (all sites), Obstetrics and Gynaecology and Paediatrics.

The ward or department, at its discretion may apply restriction for work experience or work shadowing applicants if there is a risk of not being able to provide safe supervision of the work experience student due to the area being considered high risk for Covid 19 or high Patient dependency
Termination of Placements

The Trust reserves the right to terminate the placement without notice if the placement supervisor considers the behaviour or attitude of the student as inappropriate irrespective of the age or they are not following the Health and Safety or Confidentiality rules.
Suitability of placements for children and young people in the
Trust

MSEFT is committed to preventing children and young people being exposed to situations that theymay find traumatic or distressing or that compromises the ability of staff to protect patient's privacy and dignity. Therefore, it is not appropriate for MSEFT to offer work experience placements to children/young people within certain areas/departments of the three sites explained above.
Patient Confidentiality

It is essential that students understand the importance of adherence to General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and patient confidentiality and ensure that this is covered as part of their placement induction.
Safety of Students while on Placement
Students must be supervised at all times during their work experience, they will not be subject to Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) checks prior to their placement.

Placements will normally be for a maximum of  working days. If a longer placement is requested advice should be sought from the People & Organisational Development Team (POD) Work Experience and Work based Learning and Apprenticeship Administration Team
All placements should have a risk assessment carried out by the placement supervisor/Head of Department. (Appendix 2)
Training requirements
This policy is in immediate effect from its agreement date. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via the Employee Relations Team.

WORK EXPERIENCE/SHADOWING PLACEMENT GUIDELINES AND HEALTH AND SAFETY Working in a hospital

We want you to enjoy your placement and to experience life within a hospital setting. However, it can also be a very intense experience and is not without risk. We take your safety on your work experience/shadowing placement extremely seriously and the following information is designed to help to ensure your placement is as safe as possible.

A hospital is considered to be a high-risk organisation and shadowing a clinician in a hospital setting carries with it an element of risk. We have put in place a set of rules and guidelines which aim to minimise this risk. However, it is impossible to eliminate risk entirely and you must also take some responsibility for ensuring your own safety by listening to and following instructions at all times, particularly when these relate to health and safety issues.

You must be prepared for the fact that you may be prevented from attending planned sessions at very short notice, and you may also be asked to leave a session if it is considered unsafe or inappropriate for you to be present. You must comply with any requests asking you not to enter or leave an area at any time.

Please make sure that you and your parents (if you are aged 18 or below) read this entire placement information sheet carefully. There is a lot of information to take in, but reading this information will help to prepare you for your placement. If you are unsure about any of the information provided, or about the placement you have been offered, then you must discuss this with the contact person who is arranging your placement or the area you going into as soon as possible. This could be before, during or after your placement.
Personal qualities
Whilst on a work experience/shadowing placement you will be expected to adhere to the following:
- Maintain a friendly, caring, safe environment for staff, patients and visitors.
- Treat patients, their families and visitors as you would like to be treated yourself.
- Support colleagues with teamwork.
- Provide a polite and helpful telephone service (where given the opportunity)
- Be an excellent role model for the Trust
Dress Code
It is expected that students will arrive for duty dressed smartly and adhere to the following dress code:
- Clothes and shoes should be clean and comfortable, keeping in mind that you will be on your feet for most of the day and hospital wards tend to be rather warm.
- Smart trousers/shirt or blouse
- Smart shoes, covering the whole foot, with low or flat heels no trainers.
- Long hair should be tied back and off the collar
- “Bare below the elbows” policy: No false nails, nail varnish or jewellery, with the exception of small stud earrings and wedding band. If a necklace is worn it must not be on show.
- Clothes should be changed daily and washed at 70 degress if in a clinical placements to minimise the risk of cross infection.

- Special requirements as a result of cultural or religious obligations should comply with health and safety and infection control precautions. Headscarves may be worn and be of, be unadorned and shoulder length only. The wearing of facial veils or burkhas is not permitted. The wearing of turbans is allowed on religious grounds.
Confidentiality

- It is natural to wish to discuss your experience on a work placement with friends and family. However, you must ensure that you do not disclose confidential information which could identify an individual patient or member of staff, or information about the business of the Trust.
- Under no circumstances should photographs be taken in the Hospital or any details of your placement, experience, Doctors or Patients be shared on Social Media.
- Mobile phones should not be used whilst you are at work
- You must let your supervisor know immediately if you know any patient personally. This applies even if they are a patient of a service which is different to the area of your placement.
Health and safety
- Pay careful attention to any Health and Safety information given to you at the introduction to your local placements.
- You will be given a temporary ID badge at the start of your placement which must be worn at all times.
- You will be supervised at all times and will also be given training when using equipment.
Your placement
Psychological/emotional:

- Within the daily work of the hospital, you may be exposed to distressing situations. This might include a patient becoming distressed, a patient's condition deteriorating. You may see procedures or conditions which you will find upsetting.

- Although we will do our best to pre-empt these situations, you should be prepared for them. Please tell the person working with you if you are upset, so that we can talk about the issues as soon as it is clinically possible.

- There is a risk of verbal abuse from patients or visitors of the Trust. You will not be expected to deal with any incident of this sort. If you are unfortunate enough to witness this type of behaviour, you should excuse yourself, and contact the nearest member of staff.
Physical:
- You must not move or handle any heavy objects. These can include boxes, equipment, and patients.
- If you feel faint or sick you should sit down or leave the area, whichever is the most appropriate. There is a risk of injury if you faint.
- There is a risk of physical abuse from patients or visitors of the trust. You will be supervised at all times during a clinical session, and therefore this risk is considered low.

- Between sessions you are advised to take normal precautions when walking in and around the internal and external parts of the hospital site to ensure your safety. This might include not walking in areas which are isolated, or deserted.
Infection control:

- All students who will be observing in clinical/patient areas must confirm all immunisations on a health declaration. You must also be aware that being in hospital environment may mean that exposure to viruses and other infections will be higher than your normal environment.
- We will not expect you to work in areas, or with patient groups, where observation would carry a high risk of infection.

- Students should avoid contact with bodily fluids, but be aware that there may be a risk of contact in unpredicted situations. In order to minimise risk of infection, you must follow instructions given by members of staff at all times
- You must ensure that your standards of personal hygiene are very high. You must wash your hands at the beginning and end of each session, and if you use the toilet facilities.
- In order to minimise risks of cross infection clothes should be changed daily.
- You must not under any circumstances handle sharps (needles or other sharp objects) and when in clinical areas should take extreme care where you put your hands, and check before you sit down.
- Do not handle patient belongings.
Exposure to substances:

A hospital will use a number of hazardous substances. You will not be expected to handle any substances which are considered to be hazardous. You must not touch any substance unless you are sure you know what it is and that it is not hazardous. This is particularly important when you are observing in clinical areas
Risk of accidents:

- A hospital setting will probably be new to you, and you are not a trained member of staff. Therefore, you will be at a higher risk of accidents than other members of staff or students. In order to minimise such risks you will be supervised at all times when you are on placement

- At other times you must ensure that you only access areas you have been given permission to enter, and that you only observe planned procedures under supervision. It is essential that you follow instructions carefully, and leave any area immediately if you are asked to do so.

Health and safety at work is of Trust's paramount importance. You have the responsibility to acquaint yourself with the safety rules of the work place, to follow these rules and make use of the facilities and equipment provided for your safety.

It is your legal obligation to take reasonable care of your own health and safety and that of others who may be affected by your acts or omissions and cooperate and comply with safe working practices within the workplace.

It is also your responsibility to not intentionally or recklessly interfere with or misuse anything provided by the Trusts in the interests of health, safety and welfare of its employees and other persons on their premises.

data.text: CONFIDENTIALITY CODE OF CONDUCT FOR WORK EXPERIENCE

This following confidentiality Code of Conduct applies to all staff working for the Trust and will include bank, voluntary, locum, agency, student placements and temporary staff. It is important that the following information is read and understood prior to commencing a work experience placement
PURPOSE OF THE CODE

All individuals working in the NHS are bound by a legal duty of confidence to protect personal information they may come into contact with during the course of their work. This is not just a requirement  of  their  contractual  responsibilities  and  where  applicable  their  own  professional code/s of conducts, but also a requirement of the General Data Protection Regulation/UK Data Protection Legislation, the Department of Health Code of Practice on Confidential Information issued in December 2014, and the NHS Care Records Guarantee.

The Trust is committed to the delivery of a first-class confidential service. This means ensuring that all information is processed fairly, lawfully and as transparently as possible so that patients, staff and the public:
Understand the reasons for processing information
Give their consent for the disclosure and use of their personal information
Gain trust in the way the organisation handles information
Understand their rights to access information held about them

In the course of your duties, you may have access to confidential information about patients, staff or Trust business in general. Under no circumstances must personal information about patients be divulged to anyone other than authorised persons, e.g. nursing or other health professional staff, who are concerned directly with the care, diagnosis/or treatment of the patient.

Similarly, information of a personal or confidential nature concerning individual staff members must  not  be  divulged  to  anyone  unless  there  is  a  genuine  justified  purpose  to  access  this information as part of their job role, and where necessary appropriate authority has been given to release the information.
Failure to observe these rules could result in action being taken against you, which may include your work experience placement being discontinued.
WHAT IS CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION?

Confidential information can be anything that relates to patients, staff (including non-contract, volunteers, bank and agency staff, locums, student placements), their family or friends, however stored.
For example, information may be held on paper, CD, computer file or printout, video, photograph or even heard by word of mouth.
It includes information stored on portable devices such as laptops, tablets, mobile phones and digital cameras.
It can take many forms including medical notes, audits, employee records, occupational health records etc. It also includes any corporate information, such as Trust confidential information.

Person-identifiable information is anything that contains the means to identify a person, such as name, address, postcode, date of birth, an identification number (NHS number or National Insurance number), and also includes online identifiers or to one or more factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that person. Even a visual image (e.g. photograph) is sufficient to identify an individual.

Certain categories of information are legally defined as particularly sensitive and should be carefully protected by additional requirements stated in legislation such as information relating to fertilisation, sexually transmitted diseases, HIV or termination of pregnancy.
During your duty of work, you should consider all information to be sensitive, even a patient's name and address. The same standards should be applied to all information you come into contact with.
WHAT MUST BE DONE TO MAINTAIN CONFIDENTIALITY?
Comply with relevant Trust Policies such as the Trust Information Security Policy.
Keep all work areas secure.
Confidential information must not be left lying around on desks, photocopiers or printers.
Students must wear their Work Experience ID at all times whilst on placement.
Equipment, data or software must not be removed from site without relevant permissions.
PCs must be logged off when not in use.
Passwords must not be shared.
Confidential information must be disposed of securely.

When it is necessary to verbally pass on or check confidential information, care should be taken that it is not disclosed to unauthorised third parties. Do not give out any information to the police or media without seeking advice from a senior member of staff.
Secure methods of transferring personal/sensitive information must be followed at all times.
Information Security Incidents and Breaches must be reported to your line manager and by completion of the Trusts online Incident Reporting Form.
Take individual responsibility for your actions and ensure you comply with the law.
Information Security Risks must be reported to your line manager.
The signing of these documents does not exclude staff who have genuine concerns pursuing the matter via the Trusts ‘Whistle Blowing Policy'.

Work Experience Agreement Form Details of Student
This agreement is for a period of work experience as above and, the student requiring the work experience must comply with the following conditions:
AGREEMENT
Whilst undertaking work experience students will be allocated a named employee of the NHS who will
be responsible for implementing the Trust's requirements in respect of the placement.
Students may not carry out any tasks for which they have not been prepared unless under instruction.
During the course of the placement any matters of a confidential nature, especially information relating

to the diagnosis and treatment of patients, individual staff records and details on contracts, prices and terms, must under no circumstances be divulged or passed on to any unauthorised person or persons. Breach of confidentiality is a very serious matter and, if it occurs, the appropriate action will be taken against the offending party.
Any event of misconduct or poor performance may result in the termination of the placement or in the
event of any act of gross misconduct a requirement to leave the premises.
The senior member of the relevant department/s within the Trust must be notified of any absence that
results in the inability to attend for the purpose of the placement.
Whilst on placement, students are required to comply with Trust policies and procedures and such
rules for the conduction and administration of work as are prescribed by the Trust. The following are the main areas:

(a) The Trust has an obligation under the Health and Safety at Work Act (1974) to provide safe and healthy working conditions and methods. These responsibilities are detailed in the Trust's Health and Safety Policy, which will be available on request from the named Trust employee. It is the student's responsibility to acquaint MSEFT him/herself with the contents of the Policy.

(b) It is the students legal obligation to take reasonable care of his/her own health and safety and that of others who may be affected by his/her acts or omissions at work and co-operate by complying with safe working practices within the workplace. It is also the student's responsibility not to intentionally or recklessly interfere with or misuse anything provided by the Trust in the interests of the health, and safety and welfare of its employees and other persons on the premises.

(c) Students must notify the names Trust employee of any untoward incident or accident that occurs whilst on the Trust premises. An accident/incident form must be completed in accordance with Trust policy.

(d) In order that they may practice and promote fire prevention, to know the fire hazards of their working environment and to know the right action to take if a fire breaks out, the Trust requires students to read and adhere to the Trust Fire Precautions Policy and, if considered appropriate by Trust management, attend the Trust Fire Training Course. A copy of the Fire Precautions Policy is available from any Trust manager.
(e) All students are required to be competent to lift and handle in accordance with the Manual handling Operations Regulations (1992).
The Trust does not accept liability for loss of damage of personal property. The student is expected to
provide his/her own insurance cover against such risks. The Trust will provide cover for public, employer and product liability claims for its own buildings and equipment.
Students will not accept gifts or hospitality from individuals or organisations with whom they come into
contact during a placement, which might be interpreted as seeking to exert undue influence to obtain preferential consideration.
The Trust is a ‘No Smoking' Trust under the Government Legislation introduced on st June 2007.
Smoking is therefore not permitted anywhere on site and anyone found smoking will be subject to action by the Trust.

Appendix 4: Career in medicine
The Medical Careers Scheme
Procedure Notes – Work Experience
For students wishing to pursue a career in medicine
After initial contact by telephone/letter with the Medical Training Office in the

Education Centre, Basildon Hospital,  a fully completed  application form must be submitted requesting a placement. All details on this form should be completed and returned at least eight weeks prior to your commencement date. Arrangements for a placement will not be processed without this application form. Any additional information you can supply (i.e. CV, letter of introduction), giving details of your aims and objectives, future career choice etc. would be helpful.
Once your application form has been received, your name will be entered onto the
student request list for placements, so that a work experience pack can be sent to you. This pack will include:
Job description (if available from the department)
Two Confidentiality forms and guidance notes (return one to Medical Training Office, Education Centre)
Job Description – some departments have job descriptions made up for junior work placements. This gives a description of the duties that are included in the position you are being offered.

Prior to commencement, the work placement area must be Risk Assessed. A placement will not be offered without a completed risk assessment. Due to the number of staff and students entering the Trust, risk assessments do take a little time to be cleared, which is one reason why applications need to be made well in advance of your commencement date.

Confidentiality Forms  – All work carried out in the hospital is considered highly confidential. Whilst on your placement you will learn, hear and see things which under no circumstances are you to discuss outside of the hospital to any unauthorised person. The guidance notes and forms should be read carefully, then both copies signed, returning ONE to the Medical Training Office at the Education Centre, Basildon Hospital and retain the SECOND copy for your information.

Identification (ID) Badge Proforma  – You will complete this form on arrival at your work placement and have the form authorised by the Manager of the area you will be working in, enabling you to collect a badge between 10-12noon on your first day from the Security Office located in the main entrance of the hospital. On your last day please remember to return your badge to the Manager before you leave your working area.
When in receipt of all your completed forms, the various departments within the

Hospital are contacted to agree a work placement and offer the student a place during the relevant period requested. The number of work places available varies; therefore, there may be some occasions when a student will be unsuccessful in securing a work experience placement.
In addition to the above-mentioned paperwork, the department concerned is

required to complete a Risk Assessment form covering the areas in which the student will be working (required for all students under 18 years old). The Risk Assessment then has to be approved by the Health & Safety Manager. A work experience placement will not be confirmed until the Medical Training Office is in possession of the relevant documents.
Only when all the necessary checks have been completed and clearances

received will a confirmation letter be sent to each student detailing their commencement and completion dates, working hours, name of ward/area where they will be working and a contact name. A copy of this letter is forwarded to the Manager concerned.

If you are unable, for whatever reason to fulfil your placement period, we would be grateful if you could contact us immediately so that we have the opportunity to offer the place to another student, whose paperwork is completed, and is in a position to take up the placement rather than the placement be lost.
